content.body:
I joined the Matrix server, this looks kind of like a hybrid between IRC and Discord.
I see not everybody has swapped over yet, as according to the member list.

Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders]: Was thinking about something last night, and trying to remember: Do I recall correctly that back in the day — before Bikeshed and Respec came along, back when the CSS WG was using Bert Bos’s “CSS preprocessor” service — you were the one who came up with a workalike for that tool/service of Bert’s. And that was first such tool that we started to use for other  specs. Right?
content.formatted_body: Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders]: Was thinking about something last night, and trying to remember: Do I recall correctly that back in the day — before Bikeshed and Respec came along, back when the CSS WG was using Bert Bos’s “CSS preprocessor” service — you were the one who came up with a workalike for that tool/service of Bert’s. And that was first such tool that we started to use for other specs. Right?

content.body: sideshowbarker: Anolis, yes. Hixie stopped using it for HTML in 2014, so not that long before he stopped editing it, which is around the same time as Bikeshed and Respec were happening IIRC.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: Anolis, yes. Hixie stopped using it for HTML in 2014, so not that long before he stopped editing it, which is around the same time as Bikeshed and Respec were happening IIRC.

content.body: ah yes, “Anolis”, of course
it was so long ago that I had forgotten the name
but that name brings it all back — that was great name
I can't quite remember where that came from. I expect some discussion in here?
no idea now
and I had sorta forgotten that Hixie had been using it for the HTML spec — but I guess he must have used it for years
like, at least 5 years, he was using it to generate the published HTML spec
I am disappointed in myself for forgetting — that was a pretty key tool for all those years

I think I wrote it partly to have tools that didn't rely on having access to the W3C CSS WG servers, and partly because Hixie was annoyed at how long they were taking as the HTML spec got ever bigger!
yeah the code for Bert’s thing was actually all bash/sed/etc
It was good that it was only exposed as a web service — people would have been baffled by that code
I mean, I liked that code myself, but I think you had to be from a certain earlier era to not find it a giant WTF
anyway, Anolis was a nice piece of work

I now don’t recall why we didn’t start using it for specs other than HTML — why Bikeshed became necessary — but I vaguely recall that being because Anolis ended up being pretty tightly coupled to the quirks for the source of the HTML spec
not easily generalizable/portable to use for other specs, maybe?
we totally used Anolis for other specs
mimesniff started in anolis
ah OK
I seem to have pushed all knowledge of this stuff way into the back of my memory
tape storage
looks like the conversion, at least for mimesniff, happened in 2016
OK
I assume we switched to bikeshed because it supported more things
(I wasn't involved in the conversion)
hmm among my other vague recollections is that Sam got tired of maintaining Anolis and didn’t like fixing bugs in it any more, something like that
could be
and Tab was busy doing stuff for CSS
so it was already there
yeah, something like that
Bikeshed quickly got features that Anolis didn't have, and I had long ago stopped really maintaining it (Ms2ger maintained it for a while).
oh yes, Ms2ger was maintainer when I was editing, I think
looks like encoding started in anolis too
probably others, but I'll stop digging
Plenty of others; virtually everything written between 2008 and 2013 or so used it.
right
oh wow, turns out I submitted quite a few PRs to anolis
was it partly https://www.w3.org/Tools/HTML-XML-utils/
Bert's tool
karlcow: no, I think that was something completely different
content.formatted_body: karlcow: no, I think that was something completely different

content.body: looks for a link to Bert’s processor
https://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/postprocessor/
aha

> <@karlcow:mozilla.org> was it partly https://www.w3.org/Tools/HTML-XML-utils/

it was based on that, albeit a fair bit developed beyond there IIRC
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @karlcow:mozilla.org
was it partly https://www.w3.org/Tools/HTML-XML-utils/
it was based on that, albeit a fair bit developed beyond there IIRC

content.body: those, the CSS 2 build system, and the CSS3 module post processor are all ultimately from a common source AFAIK, but have vastly diverged since (e.g. several of the tools have been rewritten multiple times)
(also hi Karl!)
What year is it???
I should make that a tradition. Come to the whatwg channel only the years of the cow. :p
Cheers all — looking forward to 17+ more years of #whatwg:matrix.org good times together
content.formatted_body: Cheers all — looking forward to 17+ more years of #whatwg:matrix.org good times together

content.body: * 🍸 Cheers all — looking forward to 17+ more years of #whatwg:matrix.org good times together

content.body: the year 2038 is waiting for us all to arrive
Happy new year!
Your old folks' tales are cool and all, but yeah, here's to keeping this community strong into the future! 🥂
btw I'm surprised I did know about Anolis when sideshowbarker didn't remember, just from the `git blame`ing I had to do over the past year
content.formatted_body: btw I'm surprised I did know about Anolis when sideshowbarker didn't remember, just from the git blameing I had to do over the past year

content.body: ah `git blame`ing the HTML source — 5.9MB of source × 17 years, source re-wrapped/reformatted multiple times — that is about as “good times” as good times can get
content.formatted_body: ah git blameing the HTML source — 5.9MB of source × 17 years, source re-wrapped/reformatted multiple times — that is about as “good times” as good times can get

content.body: and it’s pretty fun to hear Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders] getting included in “old folks”
content.formatted_body: and it’s pretty fun to hear Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders] getting included in “old folks”

content.body: Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders] will always be a young whippersnapper to me
content.formatted_body: Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders] will always be a young whippersnapper to me

content.body: cue “Forever Young” (whichever version you like: Bob Dylan or Rod Stewart)
…which reminds me, somewhere we should document that the official WHATWG theme song is actually *“Whatever happened to the teenage dream?”*
content.formatted_body: …which reminds me, somewhere we should document that the official WHATWG theme song is actually “Whatever happened to the teenage dream?”

content.body: and let’s cry too, for knowing that in 3 years, #whatwg:matrix.org will no longer be teenager

Oh wow, that's really early. I'm currently 18, joined like last year I think

content.body: Is the Matrix server because Freenode's ownership transferred? Or is that just coincidence?
That prompted the discussion about alternatives, but matrix is hoped/expected to be more approachable than IRC for a broad community.

Ah, ok
It looks a lot like a hybrid between IRC and Discord. I like it.

content.body: finding spec bugs and reporting them is a pretty useful thing
But the participant agreement only matters for PRs
right
Ah, ok

so if you have patents on something, you can just raise an issue describing the change you want to get into the spec, including some idea you a patent for, and then wait until somebody else actually writes up a patch for it 😋
and then after Google and Apple implement it and ship it, you wait a few years and then start going after them for royalties
and since you never signed the participant agreement, you’re not preventing from being able to do that

* so if you have patents on something, you can just raise an issue describing the change you want to get into the spec, including some idea you have a patent for, and then wait until somebody else actually writes up a patch for it 😋

m.new_content.body: so if you have patents on something, you can just raise an issue describing the change you want to get into the spec, including some idea you have a patent for, and then wait until somebody else actually writes up a patch for it 😋

content.body: That sounds evil
* and since you never signed the participant agreement, you’re not prevented from being able to do that

m.new_content.body: and since you never signed the participant agreement, you’re not prevented from being able to do that

content.body: I’m kidding of course
but we actually had no participant agreement for the first two years after the spec was moved into github and we started accepting PRs and patches
so all the contributions that were made in those two years — from 2015 to 2017 — were made without any royalty-free commitments
